page.title: 19THE COTSWOLD ROOF
page.content: The traditional houses in the area are {roofed with natural stone tiles, originally quarried locally. Nowadays only one small quarry still makes stone tiles, so existing ones from ruined buildings command a very high price. {The tiles are graded in size,}the largest being hung at the eaves,(some can measure 1m by 0.5m) declining in size up to the ridge, where they may be only 15cm square. Once they were hung on wooden pegs, they are now nailed to battening, generally laid over roofing felt. The tiler uses a small hammer to chip the tiles to size so that smaller tiles can be made out of damaged old ones. In at least one family in Sherston this{skill has been handed on {from father to son.
